Hi @frezhang ,
Please start by checking OBY6 company code parameters â€” thatâ€™s the most common reason why the BR chart of accounts cannot be selected. Following action must be taken to fix the issue.

Check Company Code Settings (OBY6), Ensure the Brazilian company code has, Chart of Accounts: YCOA and Alternative Chart of Accounts: YCBR

Verify Chart of Accounts Definition (OB13), Confirm YCOA and YCBR are both defined and ensure YCBR is flagged as alternative.

Map Accounts (FS00 / FS02):

Authorization Check, Run SU53 for affected users to see missing authorizations. Ensure roles allow access to BR account table.

System Sync, If this is in the Brazilian National Public Cloud, confirm that the integration layer is active and synchronized.

Establish a mapping table between YCOA â†” YCBR for all accounts.
Automate assignment during account creation.
Train users to maintain both sets of accounts consistently.
Document the configuration in SAP Solution Manager for audit compliance.

entry.title: Re: How can we print a cancelled FINT Invoice. (SAP ECC6)
entry.content:
Hi @palmeram,
In SAP ECC6, cancelled FINT (Interest) invoices do not automatically generate a printout. To provide customers with a cancellation invoice, you need to configure the output determination (via transaction NACE) so that the cancellation document triggers a print form. Alternatively, you can use FINTSHOW to display the cancellation and then set up a custom output type or SmartForm to print it.

Let me know if you need to explain more about output configuration in NACE

Please use this Business Add-In (BAdI) Change of Field Control for Purchase Order Items (MM_PUR_S4_PO_FLDCNTRL_SIMPLE) is used in the Purchasing (MM-PUR-PO) component.

You use this BAdI to change the field control in the purchase order apps .

You can use BAdI MM_PUR_S4_PO_FLDCNTRL_SIMPLE to modify the properties of specific fields that appear on the user interface of the apps:

  • Manage Purchase Orders on item level in the section Process Control
  • Create Purchase Order - Advanced on item level on the tabs Delivery and Invoice.

The SAP GUI transactions ME21N, ME22N, ME23N are also affected by this
BAdI.
You can make the fields hidden, read-only, mandatory, or optional as per
your requirements.

Using the BAdI you can change the field control properties for the
following attributes:

entry.title: SAP Cloud Integration - Upgrade Readiness Design Guidelines/Best Practices for Future Readiness
entry.content:
Introduction

Have you ever wondered where to start to understand the benefits of upgrade readiness design guidelines for your cloud integration system and how to achieve them? Then this blog post is for you! It brings you in-depth insights into the upgrade readiness concept and its implementation, with resources to help make your integration artifacts, prominently Groovy scripts, future-proof.

Whether you're developing integration scenarios in SAP Integration Suite or refining existing ones, this is your guide to ensuring long-term stability, maintainability, and resilience - even in the face of major runtime upgrades.

In this blog post, you will understand the detailed aspects of upgrade readiness, its objectives, principles and how to leverage in the integration flow tooling. With the 7.45 version in NEO and 6.72/8.36 in Cloud foundry release,  SAP Cloud Integration provides a upgrade readiness feature.

Why is Upgrade Readiness Essential?

One of the most powerful features of SAP Cloud Integration is the Groovy flow step, which allows developers to write custom Groovy scripts to solve complex problems efficiently. However, these scripts can create risks for future upgrades, especially when they rely on:

  • Unsupported system classes.
  • Internal Apache Camel framework classes.
  • Undocumented Java libraries.

Using these internal or unsupported classes may not only result in incompatibility during major runtime upgrades but can make the system fragile and prone to failures, something many of you may have experienced during previous major version upgrades.

What is Upgrade Readiness?

Upgrade readiness is a set of best practices, guidelines, rules, or tools designed to ensure scripts are clean, consistent, and ready for future upgrades. It promotes a development approach that helps maintain the stability and reliability of integration artifacts and minimizes the risk of breakdown during major runtime version upgrades in SAP Integration Suite.

Hereâ€™s how upgrade readiness can help:

  1. Restrict Usage of Internal APIs: Avoid APIs that are unsupported or pose risks during upgrades.
  2. Identify Violations in Groovy Scripts: Detect and fix problematic script patterns, such as unused imports or usage of internal APIs.
  3. Encourage Using Recommended Libraries and Standards: Build scripts that align with SAP's recommended practices and approved APIs.

Upgrade Readiness Guidelines

Adhering to these guidelines promotes a robust, scalable architecture that withstands future system upgrades. Letâ€™s explore key considerations.

Remove Unused Imports

Unused imports create unnecessary complications during software or runtime upgrades:

  • Avoid compilation/runtime errors: Unused imports might reference deprecated libraries or classes, potentially breaking the script.
  • Eliminate visual clutter: It helps streamline script functionality while avoiding confusion about dependencies.

Best Practice: Scan all Groovy scripts for unused imports and remove them to ensure clean and efficient code.

Use Recommended Libraries and Classes

A crucial step in creating upgrade-ready artifacts is using only recommended or SAP-approved libraries and APIs:

  • Avoid Internal Classes: Replace direct usage of internal classes (e.g., Apache Camel) with SAP-provided APIs and extensions.
  • Leverage supported libraries: Always rely on SAP APIs for safe system interactions, reducing risks from dependency issues during updates.
  • Bundle custom libraries carefully: If a critical library isnâ€™t provided by SAP, include it as part of your integration flow. However, be aware that this may impact flow size and startup performance.
  • Restrict OS/Network access: Avoid direct file/system operations; use alternatives provided by SAP.

Examples of unsupported classes to avoid:

  • System.exit() or TimeZone.setDefault()
  • Direct access to environment variables using System.getenv() or System.getProperty()
  • Console outputs like System.out.println()

Instead, use alternatives like SAP API com.sap.it.script.system.Properties for environment-safe interactions.

Refer KBA to know the list of incompatible internal classes.

Plan Proactive Cleanup of Existing Scripts

As part of preparing your system for future upgrades, ensure current scripts are compliant with upgrade readiness guidelines.

  • Start cleanup processes for existing artifacts adhering to the new framework.
  • Focus on creating awareness among development teams about unsupported script patterns.
  • Get familiar with the upgrade readiness toolset in SAP Integration Suite.

Upgrade Readiness Objectives and Strategy

Upgrade readiness is more than just avoiding future system breakdowns; itâ€™s about establishing a future-proof integration development model.

Objectives:

  1. Enable future proofing: Build robust integration artifacts that are immune to frequent version upgrades.
  2. Ensure maintainability: Maintain clean, stable, and compatible integration scripts.
  3. Reduce upgrade risks: Proactively address dependencies on unsupported libraries and APIs.

Strategy:

  • Introduce upgrade compliance guidelines for current SAP Cloud Integration stacks (NEO, CF) to foster awareness.
  • Collaborate with teams to initiate self-service cleanup of existing artifacts.
  • Provide training and resources to ensure developers are well-versed in upgraded best practices.

Upgrade Readiness Principles

  1. Code Cleanliness

    • Remove unused imports.
    • Write concise, maintainable scripts.

  2. Avoid Unsupported APIs and Classes

    • Avoid internal, deprecated, or system-level APIs.
    • Refrain from direct OS manipulations.

  3. Use Recommended Libraries and APIs

    • Use SAP-provided or approved APIs.
    • Replace unsupported libraries with standard alternatives.

  4. Plan for Future Compatibility

    • Design artifacts resilient to runtime upgrades.
    • Ensure compatibility with future software updates.

  5. Reduce Code and Visual Clutter

    • Eliminate unnecessary logs and code blocks.
    • Keep scripts streamlined and easy to understand.

  6. Enable Proactive Cleanup

    • Regularly review and update integration artifacts.
    • Clean up older stacks like NEO and CF deployments.

  7. Avoid Operating System Manipulations

    • Avoid direct OS interactions.
    • Use platform-provided APIs for secure operations.

  8. Train Teams on Best Practices

    • Educate developers on best practices.
    • Promote awareness of upgrade readiness tools.

  9. Utilize Upgrade Readiness Tools

    • Use tools to monitor for violations.
    • Proactively identify and resolve issues.

Implementing these principles ensures stable, future-proof integration artifacts.

Steps to Apply Upgrade Readiness

Applying upgrade readiness and future-proofing your integration artifacts involves following a set of best practices and utilizing the tools provided within the integration platform. Below, we outline the steps to achieve this:

Access Integration Settings Page

    • Navigate to the Integration Settings page.
    • Here, you will find the newly introduced upgrade readiness design guidelines, which are activated by default

Open Integration Flow Editor

    • Access the integration flow editor where you design and manage your integration artifacts.
    • You will notice the same set of upgrade readiness design guidelines applicable here.

Execute Guidelines and Check Compliance Status

    • Execute the guidelines to see the compliance status of your integration artifacts.
    • Specifically check for non-compliant Groovy flow steps. Analysis feature will show the list of affected groovy scripts. Check the version of the groovy script as well.

Open the Script Editor

    • Open the script editor to examine the issues highlighted in the problems view.
    • Note that upgrading to Groovy step 2.x can fix crucial violations related to internal Camel and stack class usage.

 


Apply Fixes and Recommendations

    • Follow the suggested fixes and recommendations to make your Groovy scripts future-ready.
    • Save the Groovy script by clicking Apply and then close the editor to return to the integration flow editor.

 

Save the Integration Flow

    • Save your integration flow to ensure that all changes are persisted.
    • Verify the version of the Groovy flow step is updated to 2.x.

Re-evaluate Compliance

    • After applying the upgrades, execute the guidelines again to ensure that the previously violated Groovy steps are now compliant.

Important Note

  • You can leverage the public OData Remote APIs to read, execute and download the guidelines at the integration flow artifact level. This will promote the automation.
  • Refer to the documentation for details: Integration Flow Design Guidelines.

Why Groovy Script 2.x?

Upgrading to Groovy script 2.x provides several benefits:

  • Future-Ready Scripts: Automatic fixes for incompatible libraries and classes prepare your scripts for future major version runtime and software upgrades.
  • Advanced Groovy Features: Utilizes Groovy runtime 4.0.29, providing access to modern language elements such as switch expressions and other capabilities. You can refer the groovy 4.0.29 for more details.

Handling Non-Compatibility

If the updated version of the Groovy step does not yield the expected result then take the below measures.

  1. Downgrade Groovy Script: You can downgrade the Groovy script step and revert to the older version.
  2. Create a ServiceNow ticket : Document the issue and create a ticket using the component LOD-HCI-PI-WT-IFL for further assistance. Issue will be fixed as per the SLA.
  3. Adapt Processes: Adapt your business processes to accommodate the upgraded script to stay prepared for future upgrades. You should strive to be on the major version of the script step.

By following these steps, you can ensure that your integration artifacts are compliant with the latest guidelines and ready for future upgrades.

Whatâ€™s coming next

  • Upgrade Readiness Guidelines for JavaScript.
  • Execute Design Guidelines Automatically on Artifact Save.
  • Block Artifact Deployment if Guidelines Are Violated, Governed by Tenant Administrator.
  • Central Dashboard Displaying All Incompatible Scripts at Tenant Level.

Share your feedback in the comment section on these upcoming innovations and provide your remarks on the prioritization.

Other source of material

  • Upgrade groovy script
  • new design guideline: recommended classes 
  • KBA Article

I hope you find the enhancements in this blog post beneficial. If you have any questions or feedback, please leave a comment.

entry.title: 7 Critical Risks Ignored in SAP S/4HANA Migration Projects â€” and How to Mitigate Them
entry.content:
Migrations to SAP S/4HANA continue to grow globally, yet many projects fail due to predictable risks that are often neglected. I share here the main critical points I observe in practice that PMs and IT leaders should anticipate from the blueprint phase.

1. Lack of Clear Definition of Technical and Functional Scope

In S/4HANA projects, scope changes happen naturally. The problem arises when there is no structured documentation, RACI matrix, or governance to approve these changes. Mitigation: Prioritized backlog + active Change Advisory Board (CAB).

2. Absence of a Data Strategy (Late Data Migration)

Data migration usually starts too lateâ€”and becomes the major bottleneck at Go-Live. Mitigation: Initiate Data Assessment early; structure Data Mapping + multiple planned mock cycles.

3. Underestimation of Integrations with Legacy Systems

Poorly documented interfaces compromise performance and stability. Mitigation: Updated integration catalog, mandatory End-to-End (E2E) testing, and pre-Go-Live monitoring.

4. Failures in Alignment Across Business Areas

Organizational silos generate rework and contradictory decisions. Mitigation: Weekly governance meetings, formally appointed business owners, and constant alignment meetings.

5. Overcustomization (Customizing When Standard Solutions Suffice)

Excessive Z custom code reduces scalability and increases maintenance costs. Mitigation: Implement a strict â€œfit-to-standard-firstâ€ policy.

6. Lack of a Robust Cutover and Go-Live Plan

A poorly coordinated cutover can lead to operational downtime and financial losses. Mitigation: Detailed project plan + mandatory cutover rehearsal + clear owner assigned per activity.

7. Flaws in the Training and Change Management Plan

SAP S/4HANA is not just technology: it's organizational change. Mitigation: Well-structured Change Management plan, role-based training (by job function), and continuous communication.

 

Conclusion

With the right combination of governance, risk management, and alignment between IT and business, the migration to SAP S/4HANA can be a predictable process with high positive impact.

If you have practical cases or recent challenges, share them in the commentsâ€”let's learn together.

entry.title: Streamlined Kyma deployment for CAP applications
entry.content:
SAP BTP, Kyma runtime (a fully managed cloud-native Kubernetes application runtime based on the open-source "Kyma" project) enables developers to deploy highly scalable, modular, and secure microservices. The SAP Cloud Application Programming (CAP) model supports Kyma deployments as one of the recommended approaches in the SAP BTP Developerâ€™s Guide

Whatâ€™s New

In the November release of CAP, we have introduced several key improvements that significantly simplify the deployment of CAP applications to Kyma.

entry.title: Determining the Right Owner in SAP Sales Cloud V2 Using Account Hierarchy
entry.content:
Sales teams work best when every opportunity, lead, or order lands in the hands of the right person. The challenge is that ownership isnâ€™t always straightforward. Accounts have parent-child relationships. Territories change. Local teams handle one part of the business while regional teams oversee the rest. And when ownership isnâ€™t assigned correctly, work slows down, follow-ups slip, and revenue gets left on the table.

SAP Sales Cloud V2 now includes a new determination step that tackles this neatly: Owner determination based on the Account Hierarchy. Itâ€™s simple in concept but hugely practical in day-to-day sales operations.

 

What this new determination step does

When a user creates a transactionâ€”an opportunity, lead, quote, order, or similarâ€”the system looks for the owner directly on the account. That part is unchanged.

The new behavior kicks in when the account itself doesnâ€™t have an assigned owner. Instead of stopping there or relying on manual intervention, the system now:

  1. Checks the account.

  2. If thereâ€™s no owner, moves one level up in the account hierarchy.

  3. Continues climbing to the parent, then the parentâ€™s parent, all the way to the top.

  4. Stops as soon as it finds an owner.

  5. Assigns that owner to the transaction.

This gives companies a way to define ownership at the level that actually makes sense for their structureâ€”whether thatâ€™s a subsidiary, a sub-division, or the global parent.

Why this matters

Hereâ€™s the thing. Many organizations have thousands of accounts, often organized into complex hierarchies. Maintaining individual owners at every level is unnecessary work. Teams end up doing manual corrections when ownership isnâ€™t found or is outdated.

This new feature removes that burden.

It makes ownership deterministic, predictable, and aligned with the real business structure.
If a subsidiary doesnâ€™t have a local sales rep assigned, the regional or global account manager automatically takes over. No gaps. No inconsistencies. No manual fixes.

A real-world example

Letâ€™s look at a fictional company setup.

Example company: NovaTech Industries

NovaTech operates globally and has several regional subsidiaries.

  • NovaTech Global (Top Account)

    • NovaTech Europe

      • NovaTech Germany

        • NovaTech Berlin Office

      • NovaTech France

    • NovaTech APAC

      • NovaTech Japan

NovaTech assigns owners like this:

  • NovaTech Global: Sarah Kim, Global Account Director

  • NovaTech Europe: Lukas Steiner, Regional Sales Lead

  • NovaTech Germany: No owner assigned

  • NovaTech Berlin Office: No owner assigned

Now imagine a sales rep creates an opportunity for NovaTech Berlin Office. Before this enhancement, the system wouldnâ€™t find an owner and might skip assignment or require manual correction.

With the new determination step activated:

  1. System checks NovaTech Berlin Office â†’ no owner

  2. Moves to NovaTech Germany â†’ still no owner

  3. Moves to NovaTech Europe â†’ owner found (Lukas Steiner)

  4. Opportunity owner is set to Lukas automatically

No confusion. No backlogs. The transaction immediately flows to the right responsible person.

What this really means?

This new determination step closes one of the long-standing gaps in ownership assignment for transaction documents. It helps organizations keep data cleaner, removes dependence on manual fallbacks, and ensures every lead or opportunity is routed correctly even when account-level maintenance isnâ€™t perfect.

The outcome is simple.
Sales teams spend less time fixing ownership issues and more time moving deals forward.

If you rely heavily on account hierarchies, activating this step can bring immediate clarity and reduce errorsâ€”especially in fast-scaling businesses or distributed sales organizations.

entry.title: RAG vs CAG: Choosing the Right Knowledge Augmentation Strategy for LLMs
entry.content:
Cache-Augmented Generation offers a compelling alternative to RAG's retrieval pipelineâ€”eliminating latency overhead and achieving up to 40x faster generation timesâ€”but context window constraints limit its applicability to smaller, static knowledge bases. For data scientists evaluating these approaches, the choice hinges on a fundamental trade-off: CAG delivers superior speed and slightly higher accuracy for manageable datasets, while RAG remains the only viable option for enterprise-scale deployments with dynamic, evolving knowledge. The emergence of hybrid architectures in 2024-2025 now enables organizations to capture the benefits of both approaches through intelligent query routing

 

Introduction

Large Language Models have transformed how organizations interact with information, but their static training data creates a fundamental limitation: they cannot access current information or proprietary knowledge bases. This knowledge gap has driven the development of augmentation techniques that extend LLM capabilities by grounding responses in external data sources.

Retrieval-Augmented Generation emerged in 2020 as the dominant paradigm, combining information retrieval with text generation to enable LLMs to answer questions using custom document collections. The RAG ecosystem has since matured substantially, spawning an entire ecosystem of vector databases, embedding models, and orchestration frameworks. Yet according to industry analyses, approximately 72% of enterprise RAG implementations either fail outright or deliver significantly below expectations in their first year [1], prompting researchers to explore alternatives.

Cache-Augmented Generation represents a paradigm shift introduced in late 2024. Rather than retrieving relevant documents at query time, CAG preloads entire knowledge bases into the LLM's extended context window and caches the computational state for reuse across queries. This approach eliminates the retrieval pipeline entirely, promising simpler architectures and faster response times. Understanding when to deploy RAG, CAG, or hybrid approaches has become essential for organizations building knowledge-intensive AI applications.

 

What is RAG?

Retrieval-Augmented Generation is an AI framework that enhances Large Language Models by combining information retrieval with text generation. Instead of relying solely on knowledge encoded during training, RAG retrieves relevant information from external knowledge bases at inference time and incorporates it into the generation process.

The foundational paper, "Retrieval-Augmented Generation for Knowledge-Intensive NLP Tasks," was published by Patrick Lewis and collaborators at Facebook AI Research (now Meta AI) in May 2020 [2]. The researchers combined a pre-trained parametric memory (the seq2seq model BART) with non-parametric memory (a dense vector index of Wikipedia), demonstrating state-of-the-art results on open-domain question-answering tasks.

 

 

 

Core Architecture and Workflow

RAG systems operate through two distinct phases. The indexing phase occurs offline before any queries are processed: documents are loaded from various sources, broken into smaller chunks, converted into vector embeddings using models like OpenAI's text-embedding-3-small, and stored in vector databases such as SAP HANA. This preprocessing transforms unstructured documents into a searchable semantic index.

The inference phase activates when users submit queries. The system converts the query into a vector embedding using the same model that processed the documents, searches the vector database for semantically similar chunks, ranks the retrieved results by relevance, and constructs an augmented prompt combining the original query with retrieved context. The LLM then generates a response grounded in the provided information. A typical prompt structure instructs the model: "Using the CONTEXT provided, answer the QUESTION. Keep your answer grounded in the facts of the CONTEXT. If the CONTEXT doesn't contain the answer, say you don't know."

The RAG ecosystem has matured substantially since 2020. Orchestration frameworks like LangChain and LlamaIndex simplify pipeline construction.

 

Issues and Drawbacks of RAG

Despite widespread adoption, RAG systems face significant challenges across latency, accuracy, implementation complexity, and operational maintenance that explain the high enterprise failure rate.

 

Latency Overhead Compounds with Each Component

RAG introduces substantial performance penalties. Research published in December 2024 found that RAG-unique components account for 36-45% of end-to-end latency, with retrieval alone comprising 41% of response time [3]. In aggressive retrieval configurations, RAG overhead can reach 97% of total latency, pushing response times to approximately 30 seconds [3].

 

The "Lost in the Middle" Problem Undermines Long-Context Retrieval

Stanford and University of Washington researchers identified a critical accuracy issue: LLMs exhibit a U-shaped performance curve when processing retrieved context [4]. Performance is highest when relevant information appears at the beginning or end of the context window but degrades by more than 20% when key information falls in the middle. This persists even in models explicitly designed for long-context processing. The root cause traces to rotary position embedding introducing long-term decay that causes models to prioritize tokens at sequence boundaries.

 

Seven Documented Failure Points Reveal Systemic Vulnerabilities

Empirical research identified seven distinct failure modes in RAG systems [5]. Missing content occurs when answers simply don't exist in the knowledge base, yet the system generates plausible-sounding responses. Missed top-ranked documents happen when correct answers exist but don't rank highly enough to be retrieved within the top-K limitation. Consolidation failures arise when retrieved documents don't make it into the final context due to token limits. Extraction failures occur when the LLM fails to identify answers amid noisy or contradicting retrieved content.

 

Implementation Complexity Creates Combinatorial Tuning Challenges

Practitioners face what industry analysts describe as a "combinatorial explosion" of parameters requiring joint optimization: chunk size and overlap, embedding model selection, vector database configuration, top-K retrieval settings, reranking algorithms, context consolidation strategy, and prompt engineering. Finding optimal chunking strategies proves particularly difficultâ€”chunks that are too small cannot answer certain questions, while chunks that are too large introduce noise.

 

Accuracy Degrades at Scale

Research by EyeLevel.ai found that vector similarity search precision degrades starting at 10,000 pages, with 12% accuracy loss by 100,000 pages [6]. As datastores grow, retrieval throughput can degrade significantly, presenting challenges for enterprise-scale deployments.

 

What is CAG?

Cache-Augmented Generation represents an alternative paradigm that bypasses real-time retrieval entirely. Introduced in December 2024 by Brian Chan, Chao-Ting Chen, Jui-Hung Cheng, and Hen-Hsen Huang in their paper "Don't Do RAG: When Cache-Augmented Generation is All You Need for Knowledge Tasks," [7] CAG leverages the extended context windows of modern LLMs to preload entire knowledge bases rather than retrieving subsets at query time.

 

 

The Three-Phase CAG Workflow

CAG operates through three distinct phases. During knowledge preloading, a curated collection of documents is preprocessed and formatted to fit within the model's context window. The LLM processes this collection, generating a precomputed Key-Value (KV) cache that encapsulates the inference state. This cache is stored persistently on disk or in memory, with computational cost incurred only once regardless of subsequent query volume.

During inference, the precomputed KV cache is loaded alongside each user query. The LLM utilizes this cached context to generate responses directlyâ€”no dynamic document fetching occurs. The combined prompt provides unified understanding of both knowledge and query, enabling the model to reason across the entire knowledge base simultaneously.

The cache reset phase addresses a practical concern: since KV caches grow in an append-only manner as new tokens are generated, resetting involves truncating newly appended tokens to return to the original cached state. This enables rapid reinitialization without reloading the entire cache from disk.

 

Understanding the KV Cache Mechanism

CAG extends the standard KV caching concept by precomputing the entire KV cache for the knowledge baseâ€”not just conversation historyâ€”and storing it persistently. At inference time, loading this pre-computed cache makes the "context" effectively free from a computational perspective. The model treats the entire knowledge base as if it were part of the conversation history, enabling full-context reasoning without retrieval.

 

Model Requirements for CAG Deployment

CAG requires long-context LLMs to be practical. Current frontier models supporting extended contexts include Google's Gemini 2.5 Pro and Flash with 1-2 million token windows, Claude models supporting 200K-1M tokens, GPT-4o with 128K tokens, and open-source options like Llama 3.1 with 128K token support. Research indicates that most models experience performance degradation before reaching advertised limitsâ€”a 128K window typically remains reliable to approximately 100K tokens in practice.

 

How CAG Addresses These Challenges

CAG's architectural simplicity eliminates several of RAG's fundamental pain points while introducing its own trade-offs.

 

Latency Reduction Through Retrieval Elimination

By removing the retrieval pipeline entirely, CAG achieves dramatic latency improvements. The original CAG paper demonstrated generation times of 0.85 seconds versus 9.25 seconds for small HotPotQA datasetsâ€”a 10.9x speedup [7]. For larger datasets (64 documents, 85K tokens), CAG completed in 2.33 seconds compared to 94.35 seconds without caching, representing a 40.5x improvement [7]. These gains come from eliminating query embedding computation, vector similarity search, document reranking, and context packaging steps that dominate RAG latency.

 

Accuracy Improvements from Complete Context Access

CAG consistently achieves higher accuracy than RAG configurations across benchmark datasets. On HotPotQA, CAG achieved BERTScore of 0.7759 versus 0.7516 for the best dense RAG configuration [7]. On SQuAD datasets, CAG scored 0.8265 compared to 0.8035 for dense RAG [7]. The advantage becomes more pronounced for multi-hop reasoning tasks requiring information synthesis across multiple documentsâ€”CAG has access to all documents simultaneously, while RAG may miss connecting information if the retriever fails to surface relevant chunks.

RAG particularly struggles with queries requiring multi-step reasoning, general queries where formulating retrieval queries is difficult, and implicit queries requiring whole-context understanding.

 

Architectural Simplicity Reduces Failure Modes

CAG eliminates several RAG failure points entirely. There are no retrieval misses because all documents are always present. Chunking strategy optimization becomes unnecessary. Embedding model selection and vector database tuning disappear as concerns. The combinatorial explosion of RAG parameters collapses to a simpler question: does your knowledge fit within the context window? This simplification reduces implementation time, operational complexity, and the surface area for system failures.

 

Side-by-Side Performance Evaluation

Empirical benchmarks reveal that neither approach dominates across all dimensionsâ€”the optimal choice depends on specific deployment requirements.

Scalability represents CAG's fundamental constraint. When researchers attempted CAG with 500+ documents on HotPotQA, the system encountered token limit errors [7]. RAG maintains consistent accuracy through selective retrieval regardless of total corpus size, making it the only viable option for enterprise knowledge bases spanning millions of documents.

 

Limitations of CAG

Understanding CAG's constraints is essential for appropriate deployment decisions.

 

Context Window Ceiling Creates Hard Knowledge Limits

Even with models supporting 128K or 1M token contexts, CAG cannot accommodate enterprise-scale knowledge bases. Web-scale corpora like Wikipedia's 3 billion words remain entirely infeasible. A 128K token window accommodates approximately 300 pages of textâ€”substantial for focused applications but insufficient for organizations with multi-terabyte document repositories.

 

Memory and Compute Requirements Are Substantial

The KV cache grows linearly with context length and can exceed the size of model weights themselves at long contexts. Researchers reported that dual A100 40GB GPUs couldn't handle CAG scaling to larger knowledge bases, with the initial loading process proving "extremely memory-intensive." Standard attention has O(nÂ²) complexity, making very long inputs computationally prohibitive. Production deployments often require 8-way tensor parallel setups across multiple GPUs to support both long contexts and reasonable concurrency.

 

Static Knowledge Creates Freshness Challenges

CAG's precomputed cache reflects knowledge at a single point in time. For dynamic domainsâ€”news, market data, legal compliance updates, inventory systemsâ€”cached knowledge becomes stale rapidly. Rebuilding caches for large knowledge bases requires substantial compute overhead, making CAG unsuitable for applications requiring dynamic updates or on-demand knowledge integration.

 

The "Lost in the Middle" Problem Persists

Despite having full context access, CAG inherits the same positional bias affecting all long-context LLM processing. Research confirms that information positioned in the middle of long contexts is more likely to be overlooked or poorly utilized, producing a U-shaped accuracy curve regardless of whether context arrived through retrieval or preloading [4].

 

Hybrid Approaches Combining CAG and RAG

The recognition that neither approach dominates across all scenarios has driven development of hybrid architectures that capture benefits from both paradigms.

 

 

Self-Route Enables Adaptive Query Handling

Research presented at EMNLP 2024 introduced Self-Route, an approach where the LLM self-reflects on whether queries are answerable with RAG alone [8]. The system presents retrieved chunks to the model, which evaluates whether the context is sufficient. If answerable, the system uses the lower-cost RAG response; if insufficient, it escalates to full long-context processing. For Gemini-1.5-Pro, 81.74% of queries were answered by RAG without escalation, achieving performance comparable to full long-context processing while using only 38.6% of tokens [8].

 

Tiered Architectures Serve Diverse Query Patterns

Organizations are implementing tiered systems that route queries based on characteristics. Core, frequently-accessed knowledge is preloaded via CAG for instant response times. Extended or dynamic knowledge is served through RAG with real-time retrieval. A retail example preloads product specifications via CAG for customer support while using RAG to fetch current promotions or inventory status. This architecture balances the efficiency of preloading with the flexibility of retrieval, enabling sub-second responses for common queries while maintaining access to the full knowledge corpus.

 

Foundation Context with Selective Retrieval

The original CAG paper proposed systems that "preload a foundation context and use retrieval only to augment edge cases or highly specific queries" [7]. This balances efficiency with flexibilityâ€”stable knowledge lives in the cache while the retrieval system handles novel or specialized information needs. The RAPTOR approach extends this by clustering documents into topics, generating high-level summaries for each cluster, caching summaries in the CAG layer, and fetching full documents on demand when deeper detail is required [9].

 

Conclusion

The emergence of Cache-Augmented Generation challenges assumptions that have dominated knowledge-augmented AI development since 2020. For applications with manageable, stable knowledge requirements where latency matters, CAG offers a compelling alternative: 10-40x faster generation times, 2-4% higher accuracy, and dramatically simpler architecture compared to RAG. The elimination of retrieval pipelines removes entire categories of failure modes that have frustrated enterprise deployments.

Yet RAG remains indispensable for the majority of production use cases. When knowledge bases span millions of documents, when information changes frequently, or when source attribution is required, RAG's selective retrieval approach proves essential.

The most significant development is the maturation of hybrid architectures that transcend the binary choice. Self-Route and similar approaches demonstrate that intelligent query routing can achieve long-context performance while using only 38.6% of tokens [8]. Tiered systems that combine CAG's speed for core knowledge with RAG's flexibility for extended corpora represent a practical path forward for organizations with diverse query patterns.

For data scientists evaluating these approaches, the decision framework has clarified: assess knowledge base size, update frequency, and latency requirements. Knowledge bases under 100K tokens with infrequent updates are strong CAG candidates. Enterprise-scale deployments with dynamic knowledge require RAG. Most organizations will benefit from hybrid architectures that route queries to the appropriate system based on complexity and freshness requirements.

We are facing a critical issue in our on-premise SAP HANA system, and I would appreciate your guidance or any known solutions.

Issue Summary

Whenever we activate CDS artifacts (e.g., .hdbdd / .hdbtable definitions), all related HANA sequences are getting reset.
After activation, the sequence values restart, which forces us to manually run ALTER SEQUENCE statements to restore the correct value.

This behavior is impacting deployments in QA and Production, and is currently a go-live blocker.

Technical Details

  • Platform: SAP BTP NEO

  • Application Stack: XS Classic (XSJS), SAPUI5, CDS Views

Any help, similar experiences, or SAP Notes related to this would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks,
Sai Mekala

  • 5. Engage with Us

Related Content:

Below is an overview of the planned blog series â€“ each post focusing on a specific integration topic. Once published, the titles will be linked for direct access:

Integrating SAP EHS in the Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side â€“ Guidebook

Part 1: Introduction & OverviewLink
Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactorsLink
Part 3: Integration of Business Partners & Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG)Link
Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise SystemLink
Part 5: Extensibility Scenarios & Further ImplementationLink
Part 6: Summary & OutlookLink

 

1. Introduction: Why Extensibility Matters in EHS Implementations

Implementing SAP Environment, Health & Safety (EHS) in the Public Cloud provides customers with a powerful set of standard capabilities across EHS functionality such as Incident Management, Risk Management, or Emissions Management. However, real-life EHS processes often include country-specific regulations, industry-dependent reporting obligations, and customer-individual workflows that cannot always be covered by the standard product alone. This is where extensibility becomes a critical success factor.

From our project experience, we see that nearly every EHS implementation requires selected adaptations â€“ whether to incorporate local legal requirements, enrich analytics, adjust incident forms, or create custom validations. With SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and SAP EHS, such enhancements must follow SAPâ€™s clean-core principles, meaning they must be implemented using the officially supported extensibility technologies.

This blog post provides a clear, practical overview of the extensibility options available for SAP EHS in the Public Cloud and demonstrates how they can be applied to real-world scenarios.

1.1 What You Can Expect from This Blog Post

In this part, we outline the extensibility landscape for EHS Public Cloud and guide you through:

  • Which extensibility options exist in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • How they apply specifically to EHS use cases
  • Which BAdIs are available and when to use them
  • Concrete examples for extensibility
  • Best practices based on our project experience

The aim is to give implementation teams a practical understanding of how to adapt the system without breaking the clean core, ensuring long-term upgradeability and compliance.

1.2 Why Extensibility is Especially Important for EHS

From our project experience, EHS is one of the most extensibility-driven domains in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud because:

  • Regulations differ significantly by country (e.g. OSHA, EU directives, etc.)
  • Incident reports must reflect local legal requirements
  • Customers require tailored analytics and KPIs
  • Integration with external safety systems is common
  • Forms and regulatory outputs often need custom structures

EHS processes must adapt to organizational legal, and operational needs. Extensibility in Public Cloud ensures this adaptability without compromising SAPâ€™s clean-core principles.

 

2. Extensibility Options in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides a comprehensive extensibility portfolio designed to support innovation without compromising the stability of the core system. These capabilities range from low-code configuration tools for business users to pro-code development environments for technical teams. Understanding these options is essential for designing scalable, future-proof EHS solutions â€“ especially in Public Cloud environments where clean-core principles are mandatory.

Extensibility Portfolio for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

2.1 Low-Code vs. Pro-Code Extensibility

The extensibility portfolio is structured along two axes:

  • Low-Code: Target at key user and functional experts who need to quickly adapt user interfaces, create fields, or adjust logic without deep technical development.
  • Pro-Code: Designed for professional developers who require advanced capabilities through the ABAP Cloud development model or SAP BTP services.

These options are distributed across two major extensibility categories: On-Stack Extensibility (In-App) & Side-by-Side Extensibility.

2.2 On-Stack Extensibility (In-App)

Executed directly inside SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, following the clean-core principles enforced by SAP.

Key User & Developer Extensibility

2.2.1 Key User Extensibility (Low-Code)

Accessible directly via the SAP Fiori Launchpad, key user extensibility enables business focused adjustments such as:

  • UI adaptation mode: Modify screen layouts, hide/show fields, rearrange sections.
  • Custom fields: Create and publish custom fields that automatically extend UI, APIs, CDS views, and reports.
  • Custom logic (using BAdIs or BDEF extensions): Implement small logic enhancements using predefined extensions points.
  • Custom business objects: Model simple new business objects without coding.
  • Custom CDS views & OData services: Build analytical and integration-ready views with drag-and-drop tooling.
  • Analytical queries and applications: Extend reporting and KPIs in SAP Fiori or SAP Analytics Cloud.

Key User Extensibility is ideal for EHS teams that need to adapt processes quickly, e.g. adding a regulatory field in Incident Management or creating country-specific reporting structures.

2.2.2 Developer Extensibility (Pro-Code)

Developer Extensibility is performed using ABAP Cloud in Eclipse via ABAP Development Tools (ADT), enabling professional developers to build upgrade-safe extensions inside the SAP S/4HANA Cloud stack.

Typical capabilities include:

  • UI adaptation projects via SAP Business Application Studio
  • Extension fields built using professional ABAP development tools
  • Custom logic (BAdIs and BDEF extensions) with advanced editor capabilities
  • RAP Business Objects (full-fledge RESTful ABAP applications)
  • CDS views and OData services with full development tooling
  • Analytical queries and custom analytical content

This level of extensibility is used when EHS implementations require more complex data models, multi-step validations, or custom processes beyond the key user scope.

2.3 Side-by-Side Extensibility

When requirements cannot be fulfilled within the S/4HANA Cloud stack, SAP BTP provides a powerful platform for building complementary applications:

  • SAP Build Apps (no-code mobile and web apps)
  • SAP Build Process Automation (workflows and automations)
  • SAP Build Work Zone (custom dashboard and portals)
  • SAP Build Code / CAP (cloud-native pro-code development, Node.js/Java)
  • ABAP Environment on BTP (Steampunk) for ABAP Cloud side-by-side extensions

Side-by-side extensibility is particularly relevant for EHS when:

  • complex mobile solutions are required (e.g. hazard observations, audits)
  • workflow automation or robotic processing is desired
  • large-scale integration scenarios (e.g., IoT sensors, safety systems) are needed
  • custom employee or contractor portals must be built

Although side-by-side extensibility plays an important role in the overall SAP extensibility strategy, we will not dive deeper into BTP-based extensions in this blog post. Our objective is to demonstrate what can be achieved directly within the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, using standard in-app extensibility options that remain fully aligned with SAPâ€™s clean-core principles. Based on our project experience, most EHS related enhancements such as custom fields, logic, reporting extensions, and form adaptations can be delivered efficiently using Key User or Developer Extensibility (on-stack). For this reason, the upcoming chapters focus exclusively on in-app, upgrade-safe extensibility scenarios that can be implemented without additional BTP architecture.

2.4 BAdIs in the Public Cloud (Key User vs. Developer Access)

Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) are predefined extension points provided by SAP that allow injecting custom logic while staying upgrade safe. You can explore the available BAdIs for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud here: Business Add-Ins | SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) | SAP Business Accelerator Hub

There are two categories in S/4HANA Public Cloud:

Key User BAdIs

  • Implemented through the Custom Logic SAP Fiori app
  • Available only for selected business contexts
  • Designed for simple enhancements such as: Validation rules, Derivation of field values, Basic calculations

Developer BAdIs

  • Implemented using ABAP Development Tools (ADT) in SAP BTP ABAP Environment or Embedded Steampunk
  • Allow more complex coding scenarios
  • Enable interaction with APIs, CDS views, RAP BOs and advanced data handling

In EHS specifically, SAP provides a growing set of BAdIs â€“ particularly in Incident Management and Emissions Management â€“ which are essential for country specific reporting, custom form generation, or regulatory compliance.

The following list provides an overview of the EHS-specific BAdIs that are currently available in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Incident Management

  • BAdI: Change of Field Values in BG Incident Report (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Incident Basic Information (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Custom Field Incident Data (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Involved Person Data (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Incident Root Data (Key User)

Risk Management

  • (No BAdIs available for Risk Management in Public Cloud yet)

Emissions Management

  • BAdI: Field Control for Extension of Amount Root (Key User)
  • BAdI: Check Amounts State and Perform Subsequent Actions (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Generation of Export Files (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Compliance Requirement Import from XLSX (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection Import (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection Import from XLSX BAdI (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection XLSX Parser BAdI (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Field Control for Extension of Data Collection Root (Key User)

As the overview shows, the currently available BAdIs for EHS in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud are primarily focused on Key User Extensibility, especially within Incident Management and Emissions Management. While Developer Extensibility via ABAP Cloud provides a more advanced pro-code extension model, the current EHS-specific enhancement points are mostly delivered as in-app, low-code BAdIs to ensure upgrade stability and full alignment with SAPâ€™s clean core principles.

This corresponds closely with our experience from project implementations: Most EHS extension requirements can be delivered efficiently using in-app, Key User Extensibility tools such as Custom Fields, Custom Logic, UI Adaptation, and CDS View extensions without requiring developer access.

 

3. Practical Extensibility Scenarios in EHS

In chapter 2, we explored the extensibility options available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and outlined which of these options are most relevant for EHS implementations. As highlighted, the majority of extensibility points currently exposed in the EHS area (especially within Incident Management and Emissions Management) are implemented using Key User Extensibility, including custom fields, UI adaptation, form template configuration, and Custom Logic BAdIs.

Because of this, this chapter focuses exclusively on Key User Extensibility in practice, demonstrating how customers can solve real-world EHS requirements entirely within the Public Cloud without requiring developer extensibility or SAP BTP side-by-side extensions.

Drawing from our project experience, we selected two scenarios that reflect common customer requirements:

  1. Adding custom attributes to the Incident Management process
  2. Generating a country-specific incident report, using custom form templates and multiple BAdIs

Both scenarios illustrate how far customers can go using the extensibility tools embedded in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, while fully adhering to the clean-core principle.

3.1 Example 1 - Introducing a Custom Attribute for Incident Records

Extensibility Type:

  • Key User Extensibility

Tools & Apps Used:

  • Custom Fields App (SAP Fiori App)
  • UI Adaptation (SAP Fiori Settings)

3.1.1 Business Requirement

Many organizations require an additional field â€œBusiness Unitâ€ to be captured as part of incident documentation to meet internal reporting needs, support organizational analysis, or fulfill local compliance requirements. Since this information is not available in the standard SAP EHS Public Cloud data model, customers often need to introduce it as a custom field.

Typically, the Business Unit may be required in multiple stages of the Incident Management process, such as:

  • Incident Creation
  • Incident Processing
  • Reporting and Analytics Dashboards

In our case, the Business Unit field was only added to the Incident Processing step, primarily for simplicity and to demonstrate the extensibility approach in clear and focused manner. However, this field can be added to additional UIs and process steps as needed, depending on the customerâ€™s specific requirements, organizational structure, or compliance obligations.

3.1.2 Step-by-Step Implementation

Create New Custom Field

In this step a custom field for the Incident Management will be created using the â€œCustom Fieldsâ€ Fiori App. You can follow the steps below to create a custom field:

1. Navigate to the â€œCustom Fieldsâ€ app from the Fiori Launchpad.

2. Click â€œCreateâ€.

3. Enter the following details:

  • Business Context: Select the relevant context (e.g. EHHSS_INC_BINFA).
  • Label: Provide a meaningful name (Business Unit). Identifier & Tooltip will be filled automatically.
  • Type: Choose from options like Text, Number, Date, etc.
  • Length: Define the size of the field if applicable.

Create New Field

After the required details have been filled, select Create and Edit.

4. Enable the fields for the relevant applications.

The fields of the tabs User Interfaces, Analytics and APIs will be enabled by default. These tabs are required to support user interactions, reporting as well as integrations for the recently added custom field (Business Unit).

Field Enablement

If the new field should appear in generated documents such as PDFs or reports, you need to enable the required Form Templates. In our scenario, two Form Templates were activated as shown below.

Enabled Form Templates

Note: The YY1_WHS_FORM10 Template is a custom Form Template. The creation of this Form Template will be shown in chapter 3.2.

5. Save and publish the custom field to make it available in the system.

 

Assign custom field to Fiori app

Custom fields created by using the â€œCustom Fieldsâ€ Fiori app can be assigned to the relevant Fiori applications based on the selected business context. Follow these steps to add the field:

1. Open the â€œManage Incidentâ€ Fiori app & click on any incident.

2. Click on your profile & choose â€œAdapt UIâ€

Navigate to "Adapt UI"

 3. Once Adapt UI is activated, you can start customizing the page layout and add the recently created custom field to the relevant sections. By selecting â€œCustomizeâ€ > â€œShow Customizable Areasâ€ as shown below, you will be able to insert the new custom field â€œBusiness Unitâ€ into the desired section of the Fiori App.

Navigate to "Show Customizable Areas"

 4. Select the Customizable Area that should be changed.

Select Customizable Area

 5. Select the element as shown below & click on â€œCustomize UIBBâ€.

Select "Customize UIBB"

 6. To add the new field, select â€œElementâ€ > â€œAdd Elementâ€.

Add Element

 7. Select the recently created field YY1_BUSINESSUNIT_IBN and select â€œOKâ€.

Select field YY1_BUSINESSUNIT_IBN

 

In the below shown illustration you can see an example, after the Business Unit was added to the UI.

Field Business Unit added to UI

 8. Save the UI adaptation for this page.  

 

3.2 Example 2 - Generating a Country-Specific Incident Report

Extensibility Type:

  • Key User Extensibility

Tools & Apps Used:

  • Adobe Lifecycle Designer (External Tool)
  • Maintain Form Template App (SAP Fiori App)
  • Custom Logic App (SAP Fiori App)
  • CBC Configuration (SAP Public Cloud) / or if no access exists Implementation Activities (SAP Fiori App)

3.2.1 Business Requirement

In many EHS implementations, customers need to generate country-specific incident reports that comply with national legal requirements. These reports often require a combination of standard fields, people related information, and custom fields that are not provided in the SAP EHS Public Cloud standard forms. For example, organizations operating in Australia may be required to submit the WHS Form 10, a mandatory workplace health and safety report documenting incidents, injuries, or hazards in accordance with the Australian Work Health and Safety (WHS) Regulations (made-up). To support this requirement, a custom Adobe form template must be created and populated with incident data, including custom fields. This requires implementing the relevant Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) to retrieve, map, and supply the correct incident information into the custom form.

The report must include:

  • Basic incident details
  • Person and involvement information
  • Custom fields required for the local legislative format

3.2.2 Step-by-Step Implementation

Develop a Custom Form in Adobe Lifecycle Designer

A custom form template needs to be created to meet the specific requirements of the report. The form should include all necessary fields. To showcase this example, we created the form template YY1_WHS_FORM10 in Adobe Lifecycle Designer and saved it as an xdp file.

Form Template Creation in Adobe Lifecycle Designer

 

Upload Custom Form in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

Once the custom form template is created in Adobe Lifecycle Designer, the next step is to upload it to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud by using the â€œMaintain Form Templateâ€ app.

1. Open the â€œMaintain Form Templateâ€ app in your SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system.

2. Navigate to the â€œCustom Templateâ€ tab.

3. Click â€œNewâ€ to create a new entry.

4. Enter a Form Template Name of your choice (for example â€œYY1_WHS_FORM10â€ including the prefix â€œYY1_â€ for custom forms).

5. Upload the form file that you created in Adobe Lifecycle Designer.

6. Select the Data Source Name as â€œEHSS_FDP_INCIDENT_SRVâ€.

The illustration below shows how the form setup was done in our scenario.

Form Setup (1)

Form Setup (2)

 

Assign Custom Fields & Custom Logic to the form

In this step we assign the created custom fields & logic to the form (shown in the previous step). This is achieved by using the â€œCustom Logicâ€ app in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, where you can leverage the available Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) provided by the system. To retrieve the required information in the form, you can implement the following BAdIs:

  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO
  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PERS
  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT

1. Click â€œCreateâ€ to start a new implementation.

2. Select one of the mentioned BAdIs above and proceed to â€œStep 2â€ (if no filters are needed jump over to step 3 and enter an Implementation Description).

3. Create and publish the Implementation.

4. Navigate to the created Implementation.

Created Implementations

 5. Select â€œCode Editorâ€ and write ABAP logic using released APIs and CDS views.

Open Code Editor

The below shown BAdI implementation YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO retrieves incident basic information from the CDS View I_IncidentBasicInfo and populates the INCIDENTBASICINFO structure, so that key fields such as the Creation Date Time or Business Unit (which was previously created as a custom field in chapter 3.1) are available in the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO

Perform the same steps for the other required BadIs.

BAdI YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PE retrieves involved person details, such as Personâ€™s Full Name, from the CDS View I_IncidentInvolvedPerson which makes it available in the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PE

BAdI YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT retrieves root-level incident data such as CreationDateTime from the CDS View I_Incident and makes these fields available for the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT

Note: BAdIs are essential because they supply data for custom and standard fields in the form. Without these implementations, the fields would remain empty, as the standard logic does not retrieve the required CDS view information.

6. Click â€œPublishâ€ to implement.

 

Functional Configuration (Assign Form to regulation)

Uploading the Adobe form just makes the template available in the system. To actually use it in the EHS process, you need to specify the form and assign it to the correct form group and regulation. This ensures the form is linked to the appropriate compliance context and can be selected when generating reports.

This can be achieved by performing the mentioned steps below performed in the SAP Central Business Configuration (or â€Implementation Activitiesâ€ app).

1. Specify form: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Specify Forms

Each form entry shows key technical attributes:

  • Form Name & Form Title : Represents the form to be specified (In our scenario: WHS).
  • Form Type: Indicates the technology used for the form. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, this is typically â€œSAP Interactive Formâ€, which refers to Adobe-based forms used for output and reporting.
  • Form Controller: Controls the rendering and behavior of the form in SAP (In our scenario: CL_EHFND_FW_ADS_OM_FORM_CTRL).
  • Data Provider: Supplies the data from the EHS process to the form (In our scenario: CL_EHHSS_AIF_INCIDENT_DPROV).
  • Form Object Name: Identifies the form template used for output. This should match the custom form you uploaded earlier in the â€œMaintain Form Templateâ€ app (In our scenario: YY1_WHS_FORM10).

Specify Form

 2. Assign Form to the Form Group: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration  > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Specify Form Groups and Assign Forms

Assign Form to Form Group (1)

After defining the form groups, the next step is to assign the relevant specified forms to these groups. This can be performed on the second level of the selected form group and ensures that the custom or standard forms are correctly linked to the appropriate reporting or regulatory context.

Assign Form to Form Group (2)

 3. Specify Regulations & assign Regulation to Incidents: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety >  Specify Regulations.

Specify Regulations & Assign Regulation to Incidents (1)

After specifying the regulation (e.g., WHS), the next step is to assign it to the relevant incident categories. This ensures that when users select a regulation in the Incident process, the correct forms from the assigned form group become available for reporting.

Specify Regulations & Assign Regulation to Incidents (2)

 4. Assign the Forms to Regulations: Finally, link the forms to the corresponding regulation. This step ensures that when a regulation (e.g., WHS) is selected in the Incident process, the correct form becomes available for reporting.

Therefore, open the SAP Central Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Assign Forms to Regulations.

Assign Forms to Regulations

 

Generating the Report

Once the configuration is complete, you can generate the report directly from the â€œManage Incidentâ€ app.

1. Open the â€œManage Incidentâ€ app

2. Select any Incident which has the status  â€œIn Processâ€.

3. Click on â€œRegulationsâ€, choose â€œWHSâ€, then click â€œOKâ€ andâ€ Saveâ€.

Generate Report (1)

After selecting the WHS regulation, the system makes the corresponding report option available under the â€œReportsâ€ tab.

4. Navigate to the â€œReportsâ€ tab.

5. Select the WHS Report from the list.

6. Click â€œGenerateâ€ to create the report.

Generate Report (2)

Once you click â€œGenerateâ€ for the selected Report Type, the WHS report is created and appears in the list as a downloadable PDF.

Generate Report (3)

The final output reflects all required incident details, including custom and standard fields, in the WHS Form 10 format.

Output

 

4. Summary & Lessons Learned

Extensibility plays a critical role in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud implementations for Environment, Health, and Safety (EHS). As demonstrated throughout this blog post, even highly regulated processes such as incident reporting or country-specific compliance documentation can be effectively supported using SAPâ€™s clean-core extensibility framework.

Drawing from our project experience and the two practical use cases presented, this chapter summarizes the key takeaways and highlights the most important lessons learned when implementing extensibility in EHS Public Cloud.

4.1 Key Takeaways

Clean-Core Extensibility Is Not a Limitation â€“ It is a Design Principle

The SAP Public Cloud model enforces strict boundaries around what can be extended. Rather than restricting customers, these boundaries ensure:

  • Long-term upgrade protection
  • Predictable lifecycle behavior
  • Lower maintenance effort
  • Full SAP supportability

All enhancements must therefore rely on SAP-released extension points.

Most EHS Requirements Can Be Solved with Key User Extensibility

A major insight from our implementations is that the majority of EHS use cases do not require developer extensibility or side-by-side applications.

Key User tools already cover:

  • Custom data fields
  • UI adaptations
  • PDF report adjustments
  • BAdI logic

Both examples in this blog were fully implemented using Key User Extensibility only.

BAdIs Are the Backbone of EHS Extensibility

SAP delivers a growing catalogue of EHS specific BAdIs in the Public Cloud, particularly for:

  • Incident Management
  • Emissions Management

Key lessons:

  • Each BAdI is designed for a very specific business context.
  • You often need to use several BAdIs together to populate a report for a form.
  • They enable retrieving structured data via released CDS Views and APIs.
  • Clean and modular implementations significantly improve maintainability.

Custom Forms Require a Structured Approach

Regulatory reports require a combination of:

  • A form template (Adobe)
  • Custom fields
  • BAdI logic
  • CBC configuration

The lesson: Form extensibility is not only a technical activity â€“ it is a cross-functional exercise involving business, logic, and configuration layers.

Configuration in SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC) / Implementation Activities is Essential

EHS reporting relies heavily on CBC / Implementation Activities, especially when assigning:

  • Forms > form groups
  • Form groups > regulations
  • Regulations > incident categories

A common project challenge: Without correct CBC (or Implementation Activities) configuration, even perfectly implemented forms and BAdIs will not appear in the UI.

End-to-End Testing Is Crucial

Because EHS extensions span UI, logic, reporting and configuration layers, testing must always validate the entire lifecycle:

  • Incident creation > processing > regulation selection > report generation

This avoids fragmented testing and ensures that all extension layers work together seamlessly.

4.2 Lessons Learned

Start With the Simplest Possible Extension Option

Always begin with Key User tools before considering Developer Extensibility or SAP BTP. Public Cloud projects succeed when complexity is added only where absolutely necessary.

Choose BAdIs Wisely â€“ Donâ€™t Over-Engineer

Each BAdI serves a narrow purpose. Trying to force a single BAdI to solve multiple needs often causes issues later. Modular, purpose-aligned implementations are easier to maintain and debug.

Document Custom Logic and Configuration Thoroughly

Because Public Cloud enforces strict structure, even small enhancements should be:

  • Named consistently (YY1_*)
  • Documented cleanly (purpose, input, output)
  • Readable for team members who join the project later.

Well-documented extensions also reduce future rework during audits or regulatory updates.

Maintain a Strong Governance Around Extensibility

Typical governance measures include:

  • Reviewing whether a need truly requires an extension
  • Maintaining a central register of custom fields and BAdIs
  • Ensuring no duplicate fields are created
  • Enforcing naming conventions

This prevents uncontrolled growth of extensions over time.

Engage Business Users Early in the Design Process

EHS professionals often know exactly how regulations should be represented. Early involvement helps:

  • Avoid unnecessary extensions
  • Validate report layouts
  • Confirm the accuracy of populated data
  • Ensure usability in real operational scenarios

Plan for Future Regulatory Requirements

EHS compliance evolves frequently. When building extensions, always think ahead:

  • Could this field or form be reused for another regulation?
  • Can we structure the logic to accommodate more categories in the future?
  • Are we using modular BAdI implementations that can scale?

This significantly reduces technical dept.

4.3 Best Practices

To close this chapter, here is a consolidated best-practice checklist:

  • Use SAP-released extension points only (clean core).
  • Prefer Key User Extensibility for EHS whenever possible.
  • Keep BAdI implementations modular and business-context specific.
  • Use functional naming conventions for fields, forms, and BAdIs.
  • Perform end-to-end lifecycle testing (UI > logic > form > CBC).
  • Document every extension early, including purpose and data sources.
  • Reuse released CDS Views and APIs â€“ never rely on unreleased objects.
  • Involve business users early to ensure regulatory accuracy.
  • Build form templates in a future-proof, scalable structure.
  • Maintain strong governance to avoid unnecessary or duplicate extensions.

4.4 Final Remark

Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is not about pushing technical boundaries. It is about using the right tools to deliver business value while protecting system integrity. With a structured approach, as illustrated in both examples, customers can achieve regulatory compliance, process optimization, and system flexibility without compromising the clean-core principles that define the Public Cloud.

 

 

5. Engage with Us
